where Qclsubscript𝑄subscript𝑐𝑙Q_{c_{l}} and Qcgsubscript𝑄subscript𝑐𝑔Q_{c_{g}} are the stochastic rounding function defined in (29) with respect to quantization parameters clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} and cgsubscript𝑐𝑔c_{g}, respectively.

F.4 Convergence Analysis of Asynchronous LightSecAgg

We now provide the convergence guarantee of asynchronous LightSecAgg in the L𝐿L-smooth and non-convex setting. The prior works mostly focus on the synchronous FL setting, but here we focus on the buffered asynchronous setting. While the convergence analysis in the buffered asynchronous setting has been considered recently in Nguyen et al. (2021) and the effects of the buffer size and the staleness have been analyzed, LightSecAgg requires quantization to enable secure aggregation without TEEs. Hence, we extend this analysis here by taking the quantization’s effect into account.

For simplicity, we consider the constant staleness function s​(τ)=1𝑠𝜏1s(\tau)=1 for all τ𝜏\tau in (37). Then, the global update equation of asynchronous LightSecAgg is given by

𝐱(t+1)=𝐱(t)−ηgK​∑i∈𝒮(t)Qcl​(Δi(t;ti)),superscript𝐱𝑡1superscript𝐱𝑡subscript𝜂𝑔𝐾subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝑐𝑙subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖𝑖\mathbf{x}^{(t+1)}=\mathbf{x}^{(t)}-\frac{\eta_{g}}{K}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{(t)}}Q_{c_{l}}\left({\Delta}^{(t;t_{i})}_{i}\right), (38)

where Qclsubscript𝑄subscript𝑐𝑙Q_{c_{l}} is the stochastic round function defined in (29), clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} is the positive constant to determine the quantization level, and Δi(t;ti)subscriptsuperscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖𝑖{\Delta}^{(t;t_{i})}_{i} is the local update of user i𝑖i defined in (24). We first introduce our assumptions, which are commonly made in analyzing FL algorithms Li et al. (2019); Nguyen et al. (2021); Reddi et al. (2020); So et al. (2021a).

Assumption 1.

(Unbiasedness of local SGD). For all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, 𝔼ξi​[gi​(𝐱;ξi)]=∇Fi​(𝐱)subscript𝔼subscript𝜉𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖𝐱subscript𝜉𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}}[g_{i}(\mathbf{x};\xi_{i})]=\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x}) where gi​(𝐱;ξi)subscript𝑔𝑖𝐱subscript𝜉𝑖g_{i}(\mathbf{x};\xi_{i}) is the stochastic gradient estimator of user i𝑖i defined in (25).

Assumption 2.

(Lipschitz gradient). F1,…,FNsubscript𝐹1…subscript𝐹𝑁F_{1},\ldots,F_{N} in (23) are all L𝐿L-smooth: for all 𝐚,𝐛∈ℝd𝐚𝐛superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{a},\mathbf{b}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], ∥∇Fi​(𝐚)−∇Fi​(𝐛)∥2≤L​∥𝐚−𝐛∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐚∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐛2𝐿superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝐚𝐛2\lVert\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{a})-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{b})\rVert^{2}\leq L\lVert\mathbf{a}-\mathbf{b}\rVert^{2}.

Assumption 3.

(Bounded variance of local and global gradients). The variance of the stochastic gradients at each user is bounded, i.e., 𝔼ξi​∥∇gi​(𝐱;ξi)−∇Fi​(𝐱)∥2≤σl2subscript𝔼subscript𝜉𝑖superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝑔𝑖𝐱subscript𝜉𝑖∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑙\mathbb{E}_{\xi_{i}}\left\lVert\nabla g_{i}(\mathbf{x};\xi_{i})-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}_{l} for i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] and 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. For the global loss function F​(𝐱)𝐹𝐱F(\mathbf{x}) defined in (23), 1N​∑i=1N∥∇Fi​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐱)∥2≤σg21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱∇𝐹𝐱2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑔\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\lVert\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\right\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}_{g} holds.

Assumption 4.

(Bounded gradient). For all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], ∥∇Fi​(𝐱)∥2≤Gsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱2𝐺\lVert\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})\rVert^{2}\leq G.

In addition, we make an assumption on the staleness of the local updates under asynchrony Nguyen et al. (2021).

Assumption 5.

(Bounded staleness). For each global round index t𝑡t and all users i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], the delay τi(t)=t−tisuperscriptsubscript𝜏𝑖𝑡𝑡subscript𝑡𝑖\tau_{i}^{(t)}=t-t_{i} is not larger than a certain threshold τmaxsubscript𝜏max\tau_{\mathrm{max}} where tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} is the latest round index when the global model is downloaded to user i𝑖i.

Now, we state our main result for the convergence guarantee of asynchronous LightSecAgg.

Theorem 2.

Selecting the constant learning rates ηlsubscript𝜂𝑙\eta_{l} and ηgsubscript𝜂𝑔\eta_{g} such that ηl​ηg​K​E≤1Lsubscript𝜂𝑙subscript𝜂𝑔𝐾𝐸1𝐿\eta_{l}\eta_{g}KE\leq\frac{1}{L}, the global model iterations in (38) achieve the following ergodic convergence rate

1J​∑t=0J−1𝔼​[|∇F​(𝐱(t))|2]≤2​F∗ηg​ηl​E​K​T+L​ηg​ηl​σcl22+3​L2​E2​ηl2​(ηg2​K2​τmax2)​σ2,1𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝐽1𝔼delimited-[]superscript∇𝐹superscript𝐱𝑡22superscript𝐹subscript𝜂𝑔subscript𝜂𝑙𝐸𝐾𝑇𝐿subscript𝜂𝑔subscript𝜂𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝜎2subscript𝑐𝑙23superscript𝐿2superscript𝐸2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑙2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑔2superscript𝐾2subscriptsuperscript𝜏2maxsuperscript𝜎2\frac{1}{J}\sum_{t=0}^{J-1}\mathbb{E}\left[\lvert\nabla F(\mathbf{x}^{(t)})\rvert^{2}\right]\leq\frac{2F^{*}}{\eta_{g}\eta_{l}EKT}+\frac{L\eta_{g}\eta_{l}\sigma^{2}_{c_{l}}}{2}+3L^{2}E^{2}\eta_{l}^{2}\left(\eta_{g}^{2}K^{2}\tau^{2}_{\mathrm{max}}\right)\sigma^{2}, (39)

where F∗=F​(𝐱(0))−F​(𝐱∗)superscript𝐹𝐹superscript𝐱0𝐹superscript𝐱F^{*}=F(\mathbf{x}^{(0)})-F(\mathbf{x}^{*}), σ2=G+σg2+σcl2superscript𝜎2𝐺superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑐𝑙2\sigma^{2}=G+\sigma_{g}^{2}+\sigma_{c_{l}}^{2}, and σcl2=d4​cl2+σl2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑐𝑙2𝑑4superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑙2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑙\sigma_{c_{l}}^{2}=\frac{d}{4{c_{l}}^{2}}+\sigma^{2}_{l}.

The proof of Theorem 2 directly follows from the following useful lemma that shows the unbiasedness and bounded variance still hold for the quantized gradient estimator Qc​(g​(𝐱,ξ))subscript𝑄𝑐𝑔𝐱𝜉Q_{c}(g(\mathbf{x},\xi)) for any 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Lemma 2.

For the quantized gradient estimator Qc​(g​(𝐱,ξ))subscript𝑄𝑐𝑔𝐱𝜉Q_{c}(g(\mathbf{x},\xi)) with a given vector 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} where ξ𝜉\xi is a uniform random variable representing the sample drawn, g𝑔g is a gradient estimator such that 𝔼ξ​[g​(𝐱,ξ)]=∇F​(𝐱)subscript𝔼𝜉delimited-[]𝑔𝐱𝜉∇𝐹𝐱\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[g(\mathbf{x},\xi)]=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}) and 𝔼ξ​∥g​(𝐱,ξ)−∇F​(𝐱)∥2≤σl2subscript𝔼𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝐱𝜉∇𝐹𝐱2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\lVert g(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\rVert^{2}\leq\sigma_{l}^{2}, and the stochastic rounding function Qcsubscript𝑄𝑐Q_{c} is given in (29), the following holds,

𝔼Q,ξ​[Qc​(g​(𝐱,ξ))]subscript𝔼𝑄𝜉delimited-[]subscript𝑄𝑐𝑔𝐱𝜉\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{Q,\xi}[Q_{c}(g(\mathbf{x},\xi))] =∇F​(𝐱)absent∇𝐹𝐱\displaystyle=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}) (40)
𝔼Q,ξ​∥Qc​(g​(𝐱,ξ))−∇F​(𝐱)∥2subscript𝔼𝑄𝜉superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑄𝑐𝑔𝐱𝜉∇𝐹𝐱2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{Q,\xi}\lVert Q_{c}(g(\mathbf{x},\xi))-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\rVert^{2} ≤σc2,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐2\displaystyle\leq\sigma_{c}^{2}, (41)

where σc2=d4​c2+σl2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑐2𝑑4superscript𝑐2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑙\sigma_{c}^{2}=\frac{d}{4c^{2}}+\sigma^{2}_{l}.

Proof.

(Unbiasedness). Given Qcsubscript𝑄𝑐Q_{c} in (29) and any random variable x𝑥x, it follows that,

𝔼Q​[Qc​(x)∣x]=subscript𝔼𝑄delimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝑄𝑐𝑥𝑥absent\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{Q}\left[Q_{c}(x)\mid x\right]= ⌊c​x⌋c​(1−(c​x−⌊c​x⌋))+(⌊c​x⌋+1)c​(c​x−⌊c​x⌋)𝑐𝑥𝑐1𝑐𝑥𝑐𝑥𝑐𝑥1𝑐𝑐𝑥𝑐𝑥\displaystyle\;\frac{\lfloor cx\rfloor}{c}\left(1-(cx-\lfloor cx\rfloor)\right)+\frac{(\lfloor cx\rfloor+1)}{c}(cx-\lfloor cx\rfloor)

from which we obtain the unbiasedness condition in (40),

Remark 6.

Theorem 2 shows that convergence rates of asynchronous LightSecAgg and FedBuff (see Corollary 1 in Nguyen et al. (2021)) are the same except for the increased variance of the local updates due to the quantization noise in LightSecAgg. The amount of the increased variance d4​cl2𝑑4superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑙2\frac{d}{4{c_{l}}^{2}} in σcl2=d4​cl2+σl2superscriptsubscript𝜎subscript𝑐𝑙2𝑑4superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑙2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑙\sigma_{c_{l}}^{2}=\frac{d}{4{c_{l}}^{2}}+\sigma^{2}_{l} is negligible for large clsubscript𝑐𝑙{c_{l}}, which will be demonstrated in our experiments in Appendix F.5.

F.5 Experiments for Asynchronous LightSecAgg

As described in the previous sections, there is no prior secure aggregation protocol applicable to asynchronous FL, and hence we cannot compare the the total running time of LightSecAgg with other baseline protocols, such as SecAgg and SecAgg+ that were considered in synchronous FL. As such, in our experiments here we instead focus on convergence performance of LightSecAgg compared to the buffered asynchronous FL scheme to highlight the impact of asynchrony and quantization in performance. We measure the performance in terms of the model accuracy evaluated over the test samples with respect to the global round index t𝑡t.

Datasets and network architectures. We consider an image classification task on the MNIST LeCun et al. (1998) and CIFAR-10 datasets Krizhevsky et al. (2009). For the MNIST dataset, we train LeNet LeCun et al. (1998). For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we train the convolutional neural network (CNN) used in Xie et al. (2019). These network architectures are sufficient for our needs as our goal is to evaluate various schemes, and not to achieve the best accuracy.

Setup. We consider a buffered asynchronous FL setting with N=100𝑁100N=100 users and a single server having the buffer of size K=10𝐾10K=10. For the IID data distribution, the training samples are shuffled and partitioned into N=100𝑁100N=100 users. For asynchronous training, we assume the staleness of each user is uniformly distributed over [0,10]010[0,10], i.e., τmax=10subscript𝜏max10\tau_{\mathrm{max}}=10, as used in Xie et al. (2019). We set the field size q=232−5𝑞superscript2325q=2^{32}-5, which is the largest prime within 323232 bits.

Implementations. We implement two schemes, FedBuff and LightSecAgg. The key difference between the two schemes is that in LightSecAgg, the local updates are quantized and converted into the finite field to provide privacy of the individual local updates while all operations are carried out over the domain of real numbers in FedBuff. For both schemes, to compensate the staleness of the local updates, we employ the two strategies for the weighting function: a constant function s​(τ)=1𝑠𝜏1s(\tau)=1 and a polynomial function sα​(τ)=(1+τ)−αsubscript𝑠𝛼𝜏superscript1𝜏𝛼s_{\alpha}(\tau)=(1+\tau)^{-\alpha}.

Empirical results. In Figure 11(a) and 11(b), we demonstrate that LightSecAgg has almost the same performance as FedBuff on both MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, while LightSecAgg includes quantization noise to protect the privacy of individual local updates of users. This is because the quantization noise in LightSecAgg is negligible. To compensate the staleness of the local updates over the finite field in LightSecAgg, we implement the quantized staleness function defined in (34) with cg=26subscript𝑐𝑔superscript26c_{g}=2^{6}, which has the same performance in mitigating the staleness as the original staleness function carried out over the domain of real numbers.

Performance with various quantization levels. To investigate the impact of the quantization, we measure the performance with various values of the quantization parameter clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in Fig. 12. We observe that cl=216subscript𝑐𝑙superscript216c_{l}=2^{16} has the best performance, while a small or a large value of clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} has poor performance. This is because the value of clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} provides a trade-off between two sources of quantization noise: 1) the rounding error from the stochastic rounding function defined in (29) and 2) the wrap-around error when modulo operations are carried out in the finite field. When clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} has small value the rounding error is dominant, while the wrap-around error is dominant when clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l} has large value. To find a proper value of clsubscript𝑐𝑙c_{l}, we can utilize the auto-tuning algorithm proposed in Bonawitz et al. (2019c).
